Message.Title: Dell is no BlackBerry or Nokia
Message.Msg: Dell is no BlackBerry or Nokia. Dell is expected to have pretax income this year of close to $3 billion and $1 a share of earnings, and it has a strong balance sheet, with more than $3 a share in net cash.

Message.Title: Michael Dell Strategy
Message.Msg: Let his offer fail, work with Icahn to do the recap, hold onto his shares, then he becomes majority owner and can continue to have a say in the company, as Chairman to a new CEO (like Zynga).

Message.Title: Why Does Dell Keep Attacking Its Own Business?
Message.Msg: July 5, 2013 Dear Fellow Dell Stockholders AND Members of the Dell Special Committee: In today's SEC filing we hear again from the Special Committee about how risky and fragile the Dell business is. To us it seems that no one has less confidence in Dell than Dell itself. As you know, we have made a proposal that provides $14 per share for approximately 72% of the Dell stock and have previously explained that proposal in detail. And, under that proposal, we would continue to hold our Dell shares -- because we believe in the future of Dell. We have the financing and stand by that proposal despite today's pronouncements from the Special Committee. We note that notwithstanding today's pronouncements, Dell has not withdrawn any of the financial information, projections or analysis previously disclosed by Dell that underlies our proposal. The Special Committee keeps telling us how bad Dell is, and despite our $14 proposal for a Dell self tender offer, the Special Committee keeps recommending the $13.65 Michael Dell/Silver Lake transaction, and in our opinion, keeps using scare tactics about what will happen if the Michael Dell/Silver Lake transaction does not close. The entire situation reminds me of the story of the visitor who overstays their welcome at your house. They keep threatening to leave, but when you say goodbye...they just don't go. I can't but help ask myself why, if Dell is so awful, do Michael Dell and Silver Lake, both very astute investors, want to buy it. And, how have they amassed billions in financing from astute financial institutions to finance that acquisition if everything is so bad? I suggest we all ask ourselves that question. Today's presentation by Dell, which we view as a Hail Mary attempt to influence ISS, to us seems to be an unpersuasive and desperate regurgitation of tired arguments. Once again, Dell has failed to convince us that we should all take $13.65 for the company. Sincerely, Carl C. Icahn

Message.Title: Michael Dell and Silver Lake....
Message.Msg: They'll be voting in favor of Carl Icahn's proposal. They made a bad deal at $13.65 and want OUT, thanks for providing the escape hatch, Carl. Things at Dell are abysmally bad, far worse than is generally known.
Individual investor are going to get screwed by this man. a lawsuit will be in order if the deal doesn't go through and the stock plummets.

Topic.Title: Old Carl just got his clock cleaned by Mike.....

Message.Msg: you'll regret it when the stock goes to $6 a share and a $9 buyout offer from MD afterwards will seem like a great deal.

Topic.Title: Old Carl just got his clock cleaned by Mike.....

Message.Title: New deal in the works per Venture Capital Post article
Message.Msg: The deal to buyout Dell Inc. would not push through. According to people who had direct knowledge of the deal, Silver Lake Management LLC and Michael Dell would not be closing a buyout deal for the offer of US$24.4 billion. The February offer of US$13.65 per share represented a significant and fair premium if the deal fell apart. Now, Dell and Silver Lake are going for an increase, said an unnamed source. The company's stocks closed at US$13.03, representing a 2.1% drop, on Friday in New York.
